When the hair on [my] dishevelled head had become wet (2)
for many midnights rife with dew (1)
I approached, touching my Kiṇai drum in order to dispell despair (4)
from within the bounds of the auspicious mansion where one sleeps sweetly, (3)
[and], while those who eat offerings stood guard outside, (5)
taking it in that [that] were the days he with a dutiful
heart would praise [my] coming [in time], (6f.)
[I] said “may he of a strong hand who covers without hiding live”, (8-9a)
[and] “apart from him who is equal to others
wo have obtained a name there is no other equal to him”; (9b-11)
[and when,] seeing me who stood there, (13)
[my] mind dull when thinking that, (12)
[he] said “Kiṇai player who goes to strange lands, (14)
you are a protection to us”,
he who granted in reality, (20a)
while [I] stood without suffering, seeing [them] as if in a dream (19)
gold yielded by the mountain, sapphires yielded by the wilderness, (16)
gleaming pearls yielded by the sea, (17)
dresses that were different and pots made from clay, (18)
was an appearance worthy ofs my hand. (20cd)
Those who talk about lands talk about his land, (21)
those who talk about kings talk about him as a king. (22)
Cutting down elephants with gold tusks, (23)
as village commons crumble, [is there] affection in those who live by the sword: (28)
belted good horses of expansive gait, (24)
shapely bells roll [and] curved Kiṇai drums (25)
those in a crowd of good chariots, (26)
[and] those with strength of fast fame/sound (27)
may you, lord cruel in killing, last long,
with an army with the sound of killing. (29f.)
